hanzi-su-wiki:
幹

Значения

Ствол (дерева); основа

Мнемоника

Слева — трава 十 (сокращено 艹) и раннее утро 早 в значении туман. Атаковать врага рано утром, пока не исчез туман, вклиниваясь 入 тараном 干, древесным стволом в крепостные ворота.

Варианты

干, 榦
purpleculture_pinyin:
gàn
tree trunk; main part of sth; to manage; to work; to do; capable; cadre; to kill (slang); to fuck (vulgar)
ствол дерева; основная часть sth; справляться; работать; сделать; способный; кадры; убивать (сленг); ебать (вульгарно)

heisig_chinese_memo: A fine mist is falling, and so everyone gathers around near the tree trunk, effectively using the rest of the tree as an umbrella in order to keep dry.
heisig_constituent: tree trunk, mist, ten, needle, early, sun, day, umbrella, dry, clothesline, ten2, needle2
heisig_story: Mist . . . umbrella . . . dry. The meaning of this key word extends beyond tree trunks to represent the main stem or line of anything from railway lines to managerial staffs. This should help distinguish it from the stories used earlier for book (Frame 224) and body (Frame 1030), both of which made use of the image of a tree trunk, as well as the kanji for trunk (Frame 194).
koohiiStory1: A fine mist is falling, and so everyone gathers around near the tree-trunk, effectively using the rest of the tree as an umbrella in order to keep dry.
koohiiStory2: By astridtops - In the rainy mist, Totoro is standing in front of a tree-trunk at the bus stop, under the umbrella he just received. Look at him smiling: even when the big drops fall, he remains dry! Great story...which I get to by thinking: tree-trunk->TT ->Tonari no Totoro. I also imagine Mickey Mouse is there too as the KUNyomi for this kanji is みき.
jp_example_words:
幹(かん): (tree) trunk
幹線(かんせん): main line, trunk line
幹部(かんぶ): management, (executive) staff, leaders
新幹線(しんかんせん): bullet train
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: In the morning, if you want your hat to dry, you need to hang it on a tree trunk. In the morning, everything is covered in dew. The grass is wet, the leaves are wet, but the tree trunk isn't wet! It was protected by the rest of the tree, so you can hang your hat there to dry.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Picture everything early in the morning covered in damp dew. Even your hat is uncomfortably wet. Now walk up to a large tree trunk and touch it—it's dry!
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: You lean against the tree trunk, waiting for your hat to dry, and suddenly you realize Genghis Khan (かん) is on the other side of it. You look around and see that all of the tree trunks around you have Mongols drying their hats under them.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Now that you think about it, Genghis Khan was the one who taught people that tree trunks stay dry in the morning!
Ru_Radicals: 个 (китайский счётный суффикс), 十 (десять), 干 (сухой), 日 (день)
Ru_trainchinese:
gàn: (глаг) делать, выполнять работу; работать (по какой-то специальности)
gàn: (графема) ствол, основа; кадры; способный; способность
Kanshudo_mnemonic: the man (𠆢) is dry (干) ten times earlier (𠦝) before the main part of his day
chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: A fine mist is falling, and so everyone gathers around near the tree trunk, effectively using the rest of the tree as an umbrella in order to keep dry.
humanum_full_description_en:
Also used as " dry ", see " dry ", which represents the backbone of the artifact. The Book of Rites: The Order of the Moon: "(Jichun month) Ordering engineers to order Baigong to examine the five stocks, gold iron, leather tendons, horn teeth, feather arrow stems, fat glue Dan paint, no or bad."

" Stem " also refers to the backbone of human, animal and plant bodies. "Twenty-five Years of Zuo Zhuan‧ Zhaogong": "If the spirit of the group is used, the insured leader will not be saved, but it is the one who borrows the money."

" Dry " can refer to the threat of people and animals. "Ritual ‧ Special Sacrifice Feeding Ceremony": "Supplementary food is lifted dry, corpse is received, and sacrificed. The supplementary food is added to the scorpion, and the animal is dried, and the fish is one. The same is true." , Masawaki."

" Dry " also means the root cause. "Mandarin ‧Jin Language Four": "Chen Wenzhi: Love your relatives, Mingxians, and do the politics; the concierge is poor, and the etiquette is the sect."

" Dry " also means talent and skill. "Three Kingdoms·Shu Zhi·Zhuge Liang Biography": "The management of the people is better than general.

" Doing " can refer to supervising and engaging. "Han Shu·Liu Xiang Zhuan": "Xiangqian Shangshushi, Shangshu five people, all his party members." Yan Shigu's note: "Qian and management are the same, words govern their affairs."

Matters or things, also known as " dry ." Song Su Shi's "Taoist Book with Teng Da" 59: "Ganzi has already worshipped him, and there are leaders in the north. Fortunately, I will show you."

" Dry " also means to establish and seek. The 3rd fold of Yuan Zheng Guangzu's "Three Battles with Lu Bu": "A certain Li Su is also... sitting in the midst of strategizing, decisively winning thousands of miles away, every time he comes to the battle, he does everything."
humanum_short_description_en: also used as " stem ", see " stem ", which means the main body of the artifact.
humanum_full_description:
亦作「干」，可參見「干」，表示器物的主幹。禮記‧月令》：「（季春之月）命工師令百工審五庫之量，金鐵、皮革筋、角齒、羽箭幹，脂膠丹漆，毋或不良。」

　　「幹」也表示人和動植物軀體的主幹。《左傳‧昭公二十五年》：「若以群子之靈，獲保首領以沒，惟是楄柎所以藉幹者。」杜預注：「幹，骸骨也。」

　　「幹」可指人和動物的脅。《儀禮‧特牲饋食禮》：「佐食舉幹，尸受，振祭嚌之。佐食受加於肵俎，舉獸幹，魚一，亦如之。」鄭玄注：「幹，正脅也。」

　　「幹」還表示根本、根源。《國語‧晉語四》：「臣聞之：愛親明賢，政之幹也；禮賓矜窮，禮之宗也。」《易‧乾》：「貞者，事之幹也。」

　　「幹」也表示才能、幹略。《三國志‧蜀志‧諸葛亮傳》：「理民之幹，優於將略。」

　　「幹」可指主管、從事。《漢書‧劉向傳》：「顯幹尚書事，尚書五人，皆其黨也。」顏師古注：「幹與管同，言管主其事。」

　　事務、事情也稱「幹」。宋蘇軾《與滕達道書》之五十九：「甘子已拜賜矣，北方有幹，幸示諭。」

　　「幹」亦表示建立、求取。元鄭光祖《三戰呂布》第3摺：「某乃李肅是也……坐籌帷幄之中，決勝千里之外，每回臨陣，無不幹功。」
humanum_short_description: 亦作「干」，可參見「干」，表示器物的主幹。

②做：幹事。說幹就幹。
③有才能的，善於辦事的：幹才。幹員。幹練。
④方言，壞、糟：事情要幹。

亦作「 干 」，可參見「 干 」，表示器物的主幹。禮記‧月令》：「（季春之月）命工師令百工審五庫之量，金鐵、皮革筋、角齒、羽箭幹，脂膠丹漆，毋或不良。」 「 幹 」也表示人和動植物軀體的主幹。《左傳‧昭公二十五年》：「若以群子之靈，獲保首領以沒，惟是楄柎所以藉幹者。」杜預注：「幹，骸骨也。」 「 幹 」可指人和動物的脅。《儀禮‧特牲饋食禮》：「佐食舉幹，尸受，振祭嚌之。佐食受加於肵俎，舉獸幹，魚一，亦如之。」鄭玄注：「幹，正脅也。」 「 幹 」還表示根本、根源。《國語‧晉語四》：「臣聞之：愛親明賢，政之幹也；禮賓矜窮，禮之宗也。」《易‧乾》：「貞者，事之幹也。」 「 幹 」也表示才能、幹略。《三國志‧蜀志‧諸葛亮傳》：「理民之幹，優於將略。」 「 幹 」可指主管、從事。《漢書‧劉向傳》：「顯幹尚書事，尚書五人，皆其黨也。」顏師古注：「幹與管同，言管主其事。」 事務、事情也稱「 幹 」。宋蘇軾《與滕達道書》之五十九：「甘子已拜賜矣，北方有幹，幸示諭。」 「 幹 」亦表示建立、求取。元鄭光祖《三戰呂布》第3摺：「某乃李肅是也……坐籌帷幄之中，決勝千里之外，每回臨陣，無不幹功。」

幹字的基本解释

幹
gàn
见“干2”。

幹字的汉语字典释义

[①]［gàn］
［《廣韻》古案切，去翰，見。］
“干5”的繁体字。
(1)指器物、事物的主干。
(2)人和动植物躯体的主干。
(3)指人和动物的胁。
(4)根本；根源。
(5)才能，干略。
(6)主管；从事。
(7)做；办理。
(8)现引申为打，斗。
(9)事务，事情。
(10)建立；求取。
(11)用处；效果。
(12)原为汉至南北朝时一种身分和地位低下的官吏，后变为供役使的奴仆。
(13)南北朝时官员的一种俸禄。
(14)干部的简称。
(15)附在钟甬上衔旋的刻成兽形的纽。
(16)安。
(17)同“榦”。榦，筑墙时竖在两旁之木。参见“幹楨”。
[②]［gān］
［《集韻》居寒切，平寒，見。］
“干6”的繁体字。
(1)通“乾”。无水分或水分很少。与“湿”相对。
(2)用天干（即甲、乙、丙、丁、戊、己、庚、辛、壬、癸）纪日的总称。
[③]［hán］
［《集韻》河干切，平寒，匣。］
通“韓1”。
井垣，井栏。

幹字的康熙字典解释

【寅集下】【干字部】　幹； 康熙笔画：13； 页码：页341第09
【唐韻】古案切【集韻】【韻會】居案切【正韻】古汗切，?干去聲。【類篇】幹，能事也。【易·蠱卦】幹父之蠱。【註】幹父之事，能承先軌，堪其任者也。　又【玉篇】幹，體也。【易·乾卦】貞者，事之幹也。　又草木莖曰幹。【詩詁】木旁生者爲枝，正出者爲幹。　又凡器之本曰幹。【禮·月令】羽箭幹。【註】幹者，器之本也。【疏】器之材樸，總謂之幹。【周禮·冬官考工記】荆之幹。【註】柘也，可以爲弓弩之幹。　又十干，本作幹。【廣雅】甲乙爲幹。幹者，日之神也。　又脅也。【公羊傳·莊元年】搚幹而殺之。【爾雅·釋畜】回毛在幹，茀方。【疏】旋毛在脅者，名茀方。　又奇幹，國名。【汲冢周書】奇幹善芳。【註】奇幹在北。善芳者，鳥名。　又【韻會】幹，脊骨。【左傳·昭二十五年】唯是楄柎，所以藉幹。　又姓。【萬姓統譜】見《姓苑》。宋時西夏有幹道冲，其先從夏主遷興州，世掌夏國史。道冲通五經，爲蕃漢敎授，官至中書宰相。元有幹勒忠，習女直契丹字，通法律，官至同僉樞密院事。　又【集韻】【正韻】?河干

幹字的起名意思

意指使干，竭尽，怠慢，徒然等。

[①]［gàn］
["Guangyun" ancient case cut, go to Han, see you. ]
Traditional characters for "乾5".
(1) Refers to the backbone of utensils and things.
(2) The backbone of human, animal and plant bodies.
(3) Refers to the threat of humans and animals.
(4) Fundamental; root cause.
(5) Ability and strategy.
(6) Supervisor; engage in.
(7) Do; handle.
(8) It is now extended to fight and fight.
(9) Office work, things.
(10) Establish; seek.
(11) Usefulness; effect.
(12) It was originally a kind of low-ranking official from the Han Dynasty to the Northern and Southern Dynasties, and later became a servant of the servant.
(13) A salary paid by officials during the Southern and Northern Dynasties.
(14) Abbreviation of cadre.
(15) A button engraved in the shape of a beast attached to Zhong Yong.
(16) Ann.
(17) Same as "dry". Dry, the wood erected on both sides when building the wall. See "dry frame".
[②]［gān］
["Ji Yun" Ju Han cut, Ping Han, see. ]
Traditional characters for "乾6".
(1) Through "dry". No moisture or little moisture. Contrast with "wet".
(2) The general term for the date of heaven (ie, A, B, C, D, E, Ji, G, Xin, Ren, Gui).
[③] [hán]
["Jiyun" Hegan cut, Pinghan, Xie. ]
Same as "Han 1".
Igaki, well fence.

Name meaning

gàn
вм. 干 (делать, ствол)
Radicals: 干  (dry, morning, hat)
Meaning Mnemonic
In the morning, if you want your hat to dry, you need to hang it on a tree trunk. In the morning, everything is covered in dew. The grass is wet, the leaves are wet, but the tree trunk isn't wet! It was protected by the rest of the tree, so you can hang your hat there to dry.
Picture everything early in the morning covered in damp dew. Even your hat is uncomfortably wet. Now walk up to a large tree trunk and touch it—it's dry!
Reading Mnemonic
You lean against the tree trunk, waiting for your hat to dry, and suddenly you realize Genghis Khan (かん) is on the other side of it. You look around and see that all of the tree trunks around you have Mongols drying their hats under them.
Now that you think about it, Genghis Khan was the one who taught people that tree trunks stay dry in the morning!
